The Battle Royale Narrative Formula!

Oct 31, 2022

What is a battle royale?

A battle that involves many combatants, but ends with only one contestant left standing.

What is the battle royale narrative formula?

The battle royale narrative formula often partakes of elements from science-fiction and horror genres to build a fictional narrative where a specific group of people are forced into a contest where they have to fight until only one person is left alive. This contest is sponsored by the powerful and exploits the powerless, who are usually the contestants. The survivor of the competition is often given some form of reward from the power system that put the battle into place. These narratives examine the oppression of various types of groups (most commonly race, class, age, and gender) and how people respond when put into a kill or be killed situation. More often than not, these battle royale narrative formulas are centered around adolescents or marketed for adolescents.

The battle royale narrative formula pervades current culture in various forms of media, including reality television. This includes shows like Survivor and American Idol. Battle royale narrative formulas can also be seen in literature through books like Suzanne Collins’ The Hunger Games and Amanda Foody’s All of Us Villians. These formulas are also seen in video games like Fortnite and television shows like Netflix’s Squid Games.

The battle royale narrative formula and adolescents.

When looking at popular culture and the battle royale narrative formulas success, we can understand its roots with adolescents, particularly when thinking in terms of video games, YA novels, and reality television shows. In order to understand this we have to ask the right questions. Some of these questions include understanding why developing as members of society and as individuals, so enraptured by a brutal, gory, and emotionally and physically violent narrative formula?

While the idea of teenagers consuming vast quantities of violence is unsettling, it is not unsurprising, for these narratives often promote a sense of identity or establishing an individual identity. The recent appearance of this formula is actually a result of history, the notion of an adolescent or someone transitioning into a new identity with increased maturity being non-existent.
